intro: Oxytropis oxyphylla var. psilocarpa, commonly known as the hallucinogenic locoweed, is a perennial flowering plant native to the western United States. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its spiny stems and small, yellowish flowers. The plant contains psychoactive alkaloids, including ibotenic acid and muscimol, which can cause hallucinogenic effects in humans. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often found in open grasslands and disturbed soils. Due to its toxic properties, it is considered a noxious weed in many regions.
